questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD because of repeated attacks of dermatitis. On examination, ulceration and scarring can be seen on the sun-exposed areas like his face and limbs. He also has reddish-brown discolouration of teeth. On investigation, urine discoloration is observed as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows reddish discoloration of urine known as a port-wine appearance. The clinical scenario describes photosensitivity and erythrodontia (reddish-brown discoloration of teeth). All these features are suggestive of congenital erythropoietic porphyria.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma urine, and feces.

The most characteristic presentation is port-wine urine or pink staining of diapers by urine. Reddish-brown teeth are seen under normal light and when illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia (as shown in the image below).

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, which of the following IFA (Iron Folic acid) tablets is to be given to a lactating mother of a 3-month-old infant?
questions.solution:
According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, lactating mothers of 0 to 6-month-old children are given a daily dose of red color IFA tablet containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid.

Weekly doses of red color IFA tablets (Option A) containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are given to women of reproductive age (non-pregnant, non-lactating), between 20-49 years of age.

Children between 5-9 years of age are given pink color (Option C) sugar-coated tablets containing 45 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.

Blue color (Option D) tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid can be given to school-going adolescent girls and boys of 10-19 years and out-of-school adolescent girls of age 10-19 years.

The Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It focuses on six target beneficiary groups, through six interventions and six institutional mechanisms to achieve their target by 2022.

Interventions include:

  • Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind) including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns.
  • Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

questions.text:
Arrange the following colour codes used in triage in the increasing order of priority starting with the least priority.
  1. Red
  2. Black 
  3. Yellow
  4. Green
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of triage color coding priority is black (least priority) -> Green -> Yellow -> Red(Highest Priority)

Triage means ‘to sort’ and is essential in the management of mass casualties. It aims to identify the patients in whom treatment at the earliest produces the maximum benefit. It is carried out at the site of the disaster to determine the priority for immediate medical attention, transportation, and admission to the hospital.

Triage includes rapid classification of the injured based on their injuries and the chances of survival with prompt medical intervention. 

Priority Colour Medical need Clinical status
First (I) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if the treatment given early
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive if the treatment given within hours
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days
Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Note: Reverse triage is used in a situation where the less injured are treated earlier than the ones that are injured more, allowing for faster turnover. It is followed in this situation to discharge existing patients and to increase the surge capacity of the hospital to accommodate for the natural disaster. Here, non-emergent patients currently admitted to the hospital are discharged to allow for the acute increase in incoming patients.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A senior resident during his ward rounds advises the nurse to insert an 18 gauge IV cannula for a patient and start fluids. Which of the following cannulas will she use?
questions.solution:
An 18 gauge IV cannula is green in color as shown in image 1. 

In the above image, the cannulae numbered 1 to 4 are respectively:

  1. 18G - green
  2. 20G - pink
  3. 22G - blue
  4. 24G - yellow

A standard wire gauge (SWG) is used to size cannulas. It is a measure of the cross-sectional area. It refers to the number of wires of the same size as the cannula that could pass through a hole of a standard size in parallel. Therefore larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

questions.text: A patient with infective endocarditis is started on an intravenous antibiotic and has developed the following reaction within a few minutes of starting it. What is the most likely antibiotic which can cause this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given image shows red man syndrome and the drug causing it is vancomycin.

Red man syndrome is a common adverse effect of the rapid administration of vancomycin. The redness is due to the release of histamine in the body. This should always be anticipated while giving vancomycin infusion and can be prevented by prior administration of antihistamines and prolonging the infusion period to 1 to 2 hours.

Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:

  • Blue man syndrome - Amiodarone
  • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the tape shown in the image below?

choices.text: Reading in the red zone is considered to be severe chronic malnutrition
Reading in the yellow zone is considered to be moderate acute malnutrition
Reading in the green zone is considered to be normal

questions.solution:
The given image shows Shakir's tape. The reading in the red zone is considered to be severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

Shakir's tape is used for the screening of malnourished children and for their admission into therapeutic feeding centers. It is useful mainly for frontline field workers. The target population is malnourished children or those at risk, aged 6-59 months (Option A).

It is used for the measurement of mid-upper arm circumference. To locate the midpoint of the left arm, the arm is flexed at the right angle, and the mid-point is marked halfway between the acromion and olecranon process. Color coding of the measurements and their significance is as follows:

  • Red is from 0 to 11.5 cm - Severe acute malnutrition
  • Yellow is from 11.5 to 12.5 cm - Moderate acute malnutrition (Option C)
  • Green is from 12.5 to 26.5 cm - Normal (Option D)

questions.text: Gray baby syndrome is caused due to intake of which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Gray baby syndrome occurs when high doses of chloramphenicol (100 mg/kg) were given prophylactically to neonates, especially premature babies.

This syndrome usually begins 2 to 9 days after starting the treatment. Initially in the first 24 hours, the baby develops vomiting, refusal to feed, irregular and rapid respiration, abdominal distention, periods of cyanosis, and passage of loose green stools. Over the next day, neonates turn to ashen-gray color and become hypothermic and flaccid.

It happens due to the developmental deficiency of the enzyme glucoronyl transferase. This enzyme metabolizes chloramphenicol in neonates. Its deficiency leads to an inability to excrete unconjugated drugs adequately through renal excretion.

Death occurs in 40% of patients within 2 days of initial symptoms, but if there is a recovery, there are no sequelae usually.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of hypopigmented lesions with occasional itching.  Wood's lamp examination was performed, and the finding is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypopigmented lesions and an image showing ivory or milky-white fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination are suggestive of vitiligo.

Vitiligo is a localized depigmentation that occurs due to a progressive loss in the melanocytes in the basal layer of the skin. Vitiligo shows a strong association with several autoimmune disorders, the strongest one being autoimmune thyroid disorders (hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism).

The lesions become apparent between 20-30 years of age. Hypopigmented macules in vitiligo are commonly found in the hips, dorsum of the hands/fingers, feet, elbows, knees, and ankle areas. These are the areas of repeated friction. Koebner phenomenon is seen, which is the development of lesions at the site of trauma on the uninvolved skin.

Under the Wood's lamp examination, the depigmented areas emit an ivory-white or milky-white fluorescence and appear sharply demarcated. Woods lamp is helpful in diagnosing vitiligo, especially in fair-skinned people whose lesions may not be evident to the naked eye.

The topical application of corticosteroids is the first line of treatment. Topical calcineurin inhibitors like pimecrolimus and tacrolimus have also been successful. Psoralen photochemotherapy, khellin, and selective ultraviolet B therapy are used as second-line treatments. In patients who do not respond to this treatment, surgical grafting techniques can be used, where the melanocytes from a normal pigmented area are transferred to a non-pigmented area. In patients with extensive vitiligo, where only a few pigmented areas are left, depigmentation can be done.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the following cylinder attached to an anesthetic machine present in the operation theater.  In which of the following scenario the inhalational agent from this can be used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a blue color cylinder that is used to store nitrous oxide (N2O). It is commonly used for analgesia and sedation in dental procedures.

Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen in the blood. It tends to diffuse into air-containing cavities more rapidly than nitrogen is absorbed by the bloodstream. Due to this reason nitrous oxide is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Pneumothorax
  • Acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention
  • Intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography)
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting

Side effects of nitrous oxide are:

  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Bone marrow depression
  • Teratogenicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text:
Match the given amniotic fluid findings with their respective causative condition.
Color of amniotic fluid Conditions
1. Dark maroon a. Rh-incompatibility
2. Green

b. Fetal distress
3. Golden-yellow c. Post-maturity
4. Saffron d. Abruptio placenta
  e. Intrauterine fetal demise
questions.solution:
Abnormal color of the Amniotic fluid and their causes are as follows

Color of amniotic fluid Conditions
1. Dark maroon d. Abruptio placenta
2. Green

b. Fetal distress
3. Golden-yellow a. Rh-incompatibility 
4. Saffron c. Post-maturity 
   

Amniotic fluid in early pregnancy is colorless, but near term it becomes pale straw-colored due to the presence of exfoliated lanugo and epidermal cells from the fetal skin. Golden-colored amniotic fluid is seen in Rh incompatibility. This appearance is due to excess bilirubin in the amniotic fluid due to the hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

Meconium stained (green) amniotic fluid is suggestive of fetal distress.

In a post-term (> 42 weeks) pregnancy, the amniotic fluid is found to be Saffron in color.

In intrauterine death ( absent fetal movements and FHS absent on doppler), a tobacco juice-colored amniotic fluid is seen. The dark color is due to the frequent presence of old HbA.

Dark red/maroon colored amniotic fluid is seen in concealed accidental hemorrhage as in cases of abruptio placenta.

questions.text: You are an intern working in the emergency department. Your resident asks you to insert Foley's catheter in a patient. You try inserting orange coded Foleys catheter but it is not possible to insert. You ask a paramedical staff to get a smaller catheter. Which one of the following catheter would you ask for?
questions.solution:
The Foley's catheter coded with green color is smaller than the orange colored one. Therefore, this should be used in the patient. All other colors mentioned are larger than the orange coded catheters.

The size of the urine catheters are measured by French (Fr).  The French scale refers to the external diameter of the catheter, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

In a patient, if there is difficulty in catheterization, a lower Fr number should be used instead.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: You notice that a patient is given an inhalational anesthetic through a yellow-colored vaporizer during daycare surgery. Which of the following gases would you expect it to contain?
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane is the inhaled anesthetic, delivered through a yellow-colored vaporizer.

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent. Its non-pungency and rapid onset make it an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients.

Sevoflurane is the inhalational anesthetic of choice for daycare surgery. The low blood-gas partition coefficient (0.69), blood–brain coefficient (1.7), and minimal airway irritation of sevoflurane promote rapid induction and rapid recovery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of chronic rhinosinusitis is referred to the dermatology OPD for abnormal-looking nails as shown in the image. Which of the following is not a feature of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the above image is yellow nail syndrome. It is associated with lymphedema, which is non-pitting.

It is a rare disease characterized by the classical triad of:

  • Yellow dystrophic nails, due to thickening of nails
  • Primary lymphedema (due to underdevelopment of the lymphatic vessels)
  • Pleural effusion

Other common manifestations include chronic rhinosinusitis, chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis, increased risk of malignancy.

It is also associated with D-penicillamine therapy and nephrotic syndrome. Hypothyroidism and AIDS may show yellow nails, but it is unclear whether this is due to yellow nail syndrome or simply due to retarded growth.

questions.text: Which of the following vacutainers is incorrectly matched with their clinical use?

choices.text: Purple vacutainer - Routine hematological studies like CBC

questions.solution:
Grey vacutainers are used for the estimation of blood glucose. It contains sodium fluoride which inhibits glycolysis. For HLA typing and DNA studies, yellow vacutainers containing acid-citrate dextrose are used.

Other options:

Option A: Red vacutainers contain no additives. They are used for serum chemistry tests, serology tests, and in blood banks, where serum is required for cross-matching.

Option B: Purple vacutainers contain EDTA. It is used for routine hematological studies like CBC (Complete blood counts).

Option C: Blue vacutainers contain citrate. It is used for coagulation studies.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

2. Phosphorus b. Cherry-red
3. Hydrogen sulfide c. Dark-brown

questions.solution:
The correct matches are:

Poisoning Color in Livor Mortis
1. Hydrocyanic acid d. Bright red
2. Phosphorus c. Dark-brown
3. Hydrogen sulfide a. Bluish-green
4. Carbon monoxide b. Cherry-red

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presenting with photophobia, sweating,  joint pains, and puffy, painful, pinkish hands and feet, is suspected to have pink disease caused due to a chronic metal poisoning. Which of the following is not associated with the poisoning by this metal?
questions.solution:
Pink disease is seen in chronic mercury poisoning. Aldrich mees lines are characteristic of chronic arsenic poisoning, not mercury.

Pink disease or acrodynia occurs due to an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction resulting from chronic exposure to mercury and is seen particularly in children. The onset is insidious with anorexia, sweating, skin rash, insomnia, and photophobia. Hands and feet become puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated joint pain, paresthesia, shedding of teeth, and skin peeling are also seen.

Other eponymous features associated with mercury poisoning:

  • Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.
  • Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury. The industrial discharges of mercury into Minamata Bay in Japan became biomethylated to form methyl mercury, which then accumulated in fish. On consumption of these fishes, people developed visual deficits and several neurological manifestations such as loss of sensation, gait, memory, cognition, etc.
  • Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.
  • Mercuria lentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapor. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

The image below shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient came to the Suraksha clinic with the following presentation in the right inguinal region.  Which of the following kits should be given to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The black kit should be used for the treatment of this patient. In the image shown above, the groove sign is seen in the inguinal region. It is the characteristic feature of lymphogranuloma venereum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

The black kit comprises of tablet azithromycin 1 gm single dose + tablet doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 21 days.

It is used in the following presentation:

  • Swelling in the inguinal region may be painful
  • The preceding history of genital ulcer or discharge
  • Systemic symptoms like malaise, fever, etc.

All partners in the last 3 weeks should be treated.

Other options:

Option A - The grey kit is used in men for urethral discharge and scrotal swelling. All recent partners should be treated. However, when used for cervical discharge in women, only symptomatic male partners need to be treated.

Option B - The blue kit is used in non-herpetic genital ulcer disease when the patient is allergic to penicillin. All partners in the last 3 months should be treated.

Option C - The red kit is used in herpetic genital ulcer disease, in which the treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: During an ophthalmoscopic examination of a patient in bright light, you notice that the fundus has a golden yellow color in the light-adapted state. The same patient is made to sit in a dark room and a subsequent examination reveals a normal fundus after prolonged dark adaptation. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This unusual presentation of the fundus showing a golden yellow color in light and a normal color in dark adaptation is known as Mizuo or Mizuo–Nakamura phenomenon and is seen in Oguchi's disease.

It is a type of congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus. The following image shows a comparison in the fundus appearances ("A" shows the golden yellow color of the fundus in a light-adapted state; "B" shows normal-appearing funds after prolonged dark adaptation of 3 to 4 hours).

Rod function is absent even after 30 minutes of dark adaptation (normal dark adaptation time is 20–30 mins) but recovers to a near-normal level after a long period of dark adaptation (4 hours).

Congenital stationary night blindness refers to a group of disorders characterised by infantile-onset nyctalopia but non-progressive retinal dysfunction.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a specimen from a patient with amyloidosis. When amyloid is stained with Congo red and visualized under ordinary light, which color does it acquire?
questions.solution:
When amyloid is stained with Congo red and is visualized under ordinary light, it shows red colour.

Amyloidosis results from the abnormal folding of proteins, which become insoluble, get aggregated, and are deposited as fibrils in extracellular tissues. Normally, misfolded proteins are degraded. Amyloid may be systemic (generalized), involving several organ systems, or it may be localized to a single organ.

The histologic diagnosis of amyloid is based almost entirely on its staining characteristics:

1. Light microscopy with hematoxylin and eosin stain: Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance in extracellular space.

2. Congo red stain: 

  • Under ordinary light, it imparts a pink or red color to tissue deposits.
  • Under the polarizing microscope, it imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits.

Images below show amyloid stained with congo red stain, under ordinary light, and under polarised light respectively

3. Electron microscopy: All types of amyloid are seen as continuous, nonbranching, nonoriented, thin fibrils

4. X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy: Characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation of amyloid is seen. This conformation is actually responsible for the Congo red staining and birefringence of amyloid.
